node.contents: Since you only modify the `cache` field in the constructor you should make it `final` instead: http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/third_edition/html/memory.html#64946

astNode.text: Since you only modify the `cache` field in the constructor you should make it `final` instead: http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/third_edition/html/memory.html#64946

node.contents: I want to make my class thread-safe without large overhead. The instances will be seldom used concurrently, but it may happen. Most of the class is immutable, there's only one mutable member used as a cache:

astNode.text: I want to make my class thread-safe without large overhead. The instances will be seldom used concurrently, but it may happen. Most of the class is immutable, there's only one mutable member used as a cache:

elements.contents: private volatile SoftReference<Map<String, Something>> cache = new SoftReference(null);

units.rawText: private volatile SoftReference<Map<String, Something>> cache = new SoftReference(null);

node.contents: which gets assigned in the constructor (not shared) like

elements.contents: Map<String, Something> tmp = new HashMap<String, Something>(); tmp.put("a", new Something("a"); tmp.put("b", new Something("b"); cache = new SoftReference(tmp);

units.rawText: Map<String, Something> tmp = new HashMap<String, Something>(); tmp.put("a", new Something("a"); tmp.put("b", new Something("b"); cache = new SoftReference(tmp);

node.contents: After the assignment, the map gets never modified.

node.contents: It's no problem, when two threads compute the cache in parallel, since the value will be the same. The additional overhead of the word done twice is acceptable.

astNode.text: It's no problem, when two threads compute the cache in parallel, since the value will be the same. The additional overhead of the word done twice is acceptable.

node.contents: When a thread wouldn't see the value computed by another tread, it'd compute it unnecessary, and this is acceptable. This wouldn't happen because of volatile. When a thread sees value computed by another tread, it's fine.

astNode.text: When a thread wouldn't see the value computed by another tread, it'd compute it unnecessary, and this is acceptable. This wouldn't happen because of volatile. When a thread sees value computed by another tread, it's fine.

node.contents: The only possible problem would be a thread seeing inconsistent state (e.g. a partly filled map). Can this happen?

astNode.text: The only possible problem would be a thread seeing inconsistent state (e.g. a partly filled map). Can this happen?

node.contents:
1. I really want the whole map being softly referenced, there's no use for a map using soft keys or values here.

  2. I know about ConcurrentHashMap and will maybe use it anyway, but I'm curious, if using volatile only works.

  2. I know about ConcurrentHashMap and will maybe use it anyway, but I'm curious, if using volatile only works.

node.contents: The only possible problem would be a thread seeing inconsistent state (e.g. a partly filled map). Can this happen?

astNode.text: The only possible problem would be a thread seeing inconsistent state (e.g. a partly filled map). Can this happen?

node.contents: No. Actions performed within a thread must be performed as if they had been executed in order. Writing a volatile variable happens-before any read of that value. Hence, initialization of the map happens-before any thread reading the reference to the map from the field.

astNode.text: No. Actions performed within a thread must be performed as if they had been executed in order. Writing a volatile variable happens-before any read of that value. Hence, initialization of the map happens-before any thread reading the reference to the map from the field.

node.contents: *"Without volatile, it will be visible to other threads in a short period of time."* - Some random portion of the map would be visible, which needn't be a consistent map at all.

astNode.text: *"Without volatile, it will be visible to other threads in a short period of time."* - Some random portion of the map would be visible, which needn't be a consistent map at all.

node.contents: @maaartinus, you can actually keep the `cache` variable non-volatile but then you need some volatile write (or `unsafe.putObjectVolatile` better), after finishing initialization of the map and after constructing `new SoftReference(tmp)` [or just `unsafe.putObjectVolatile(this, seedOfCache`, tmp) to set `cache`]. That derails the topic too much though, so I am not going to elaborate further.

That derails the topic too much though, so I am not going to elaborate further.

node.contents: @Peter, in my experience SoftRef have really decent performance, their life expectancy is based on the free heap available (it's documented as well), they are close to free compared to anything w/ eviction policy. Sun is using them quite liberally as well.

astNode.text: @Peter, in my experience SoftRef have really decent performance, their life expectancy is based on the free heap available (it's documented as well), they are close to free compared to anything w/ eviction policy. Sun is using them quite liberally as well.

node.contents: @bestsss, I agree the overhead is small. Sun tends to use them with object which are not expensive to replace. The more benefit you get from your cache, the more expensive it is to just drop it. It does add some complexity to your code as you have to check various null values and recreate the HashMap as required.

astNode.text: @bestsss, I agree the overhead is small. Sun tends to use them with object which are not expensive to replace. The more benefit you get from your cache, the more expensive it is to just drop it. It does add some complexity to your code as you have to check various null values and recreate the HashMap as required.

node.contents: "The volatile doesn't make any operation safe here." What do you mean by "operation"? What do you mean by "safe"? At the very least, volatile will guarantee that the cache is visible to other threads.

astNode.text: "The volatile doesn't make any operation safe here." What do you mean by "operation"? What do you mean by "safe"? At the very least, volatile will guarantee that the cache is visible to other threads.

node.contents: *"The problem with using a soft reference is that you can lose the whole map/cache after a GC."* - Yes, I know. The cache is needed during the construction, where it gets protected by a strong reference. Thereafter it may or may not be useful, that's why I do it this way. No eviction policy can help, any missing element would lead to a wrong result, only the whole Map is useful.

astNode.text: *"The problem with using a soft reference is that you can lose the whole map/cache after a GC."* - Yes, I know. The cache is needed during the construction, where it gets protected by a strong reference. Thereafter it may or may not be useful, that's why I do it this way. No eviction policy can help, any missing element would lead to a wrong result, only the whole Map is useful.

node.contents: Without volatile, it will be visible to other threads in a short period of time. Before assigning to the cache, you need to check if it need to be created/recreated, between the check and the creation, another thread could create the same cache, with or without volatile.

astNode.text: Without volatile, it will be visible to other threads in a short period of time. Before assigning to the cache, you need to check if it need to be created/recreated, between the check and the creation, another thread could create the same cache, with or without volatile.

node.contents: @Peter, imo the behavior that N threads can recreate cache and dump is (usually) considered acceptable, unless there is very high contention and the needed object (cache) is really large. Then you might need to allow not so many threads (doing w/ one can cause starvation after a very bad thread schedule)

astNode.text: @Peter, imo the behavior that N threads can recreate cache and dump is (usually) considered acceptable, unless there is very high contention and the needed object (cache) is really large. Then you might need to allow not so many threads (doing w/ one can cause starvation after a very bad thread schedule)

node.contents: If the field is not volatile, you will either see the complete map or not at all, you are only protecting the first reference lookup of the the SoftReference. The reason I queried this is that on one hand you have a reference which will randomly disappear (the soft reference) but you want to place some guarantees on when it will appear. Its a bit like insisting on using StrictMath.random() instead of Math.random().

astNode.text: If the field is not volatile, you will either see the complete map or not at all, you are only protecting the first reference lookup of the the SoftReference. The reason I queried this is that on one hand you have a reference which will randomly disappear (the soft reference) but you want to place some guarantees on when it will appear. Its a bit like insisting on using StrictMath.random() instead of Math.random().

node.contents: The problem with using a soft reference is that you can lose the whole map/cache after a GC. This means the performance of your application can be hit very hard. You are better off using a cache with an eviction policy so that you never have this problem.

astNode.text: The problem with using a soft reference is that you can lose the whole map/cache after a GC. This means the performance of your application can be hit very hard. You are better off using a cache with an eviction policy so that you never have this problem.
